actions.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Judiciary.
Committee on Judiciary. Ordered to be reported with an amendment in the nature of a substitute favorably.
Committee on Judiciary. Reported to Senate by Senator Hatch with an amendment in the nature of a substitute. Without written report.
Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 546.
By Senator Hatch from Committee on Judiciary filed written report under the authority of the order of Aug 2, 96. Report No. 104-359.

official_title: A bill to prohibit economic espionage, to provide for the protection of United States proprietary economic information in interstate and foreign commerce, and for other purposes.

summary.text: Industrial Espionage Act of 1996 - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit, with the intent to injure any owner of proprietary economic information having a value of at least $100,000 and to convert it to his or another's use or benefit, knowingly: (1) stealing or, without authorization, taking such information; (2) reproducing, delivering, or communicating such information without authorization; (3) receiving, buying, or possessing such information knowing it to have been taken or converted without authorization; or (4) attempting, soliciting another, or conspiring to commit such an offense. Prescribes a fine of up to $250,000 and up to ten years' imprisonment for individuals, and a fine of up to the greater of $10 million or twice the economic value of the information for corporations, for violations of this Act. Provides for the forfeiture of property that is used to commit such violation or that constitutes or is derived from proceeds obtained as the result of such violation. Authorizes: (1) the President, to the extent consistent with international agreements, to prohibit for up to five years the importation or exportation of merchandise produced, made, assembled, or manufactured by a person convicted of any such offense, or in the case of an organization convicted of such offense, its successor entity or entities; and (2) the Secretary of the Treasury to impose a civil penalty of up to the greater of five times the value of the exports or imports involved or $100,000 for violations of any such presidential order. Subjects any merchandise imported or exported in violation of such an order subject to seizure and forfeiture. Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) the applicability of this Act outside the United States; (2) the preservation of confidentiality of proprietary economic information in judicial proceedings under this Act; and (3) use of a violation of this Act as a predicate offense under any other law. Includes economic espionage among the offenses with respect to which the Attorney General may authorize an application for, and a Federal judge may grant, an order authorizing interception of wire, oral, or electronic communications.

titles.title: A bill to prohibit economic espionage, to provide for the protection of United States proprietary economic information in interstate and foreign commerce, and for other purposes.
